comment_text.mn104:2.1: When this event is mentioned at DN 29:1.3 the Buddha is also in the Sakyan lands, but in a mango grove belonging to a group of Sakyans named Vedhaññā. Both texts tell the story of Cunda conveying the news via Ānanda at Sāma, which was presumably near the mango grove. It does seem strange that two distinct discourses are recorded from the same prompt, but then, why shouldn’t the Buddha give more than one teaching on such an important topic? At DN 33:1.6.1 the Buddha is at Pāvā in the Mallian lands, and the discourse is spoken by Sāriputta there. Given the evident lateness of DN 33, this is a less convincing framework. A parallel to MN 104 (MA 196 at T i 752c12) says he was in the Vajjian lands at the time; both Sakya and Vajji border on Mallā.
comment_text.mn104:2.2: While this description of the Jains might seem like sheer sectarian calumny, it is a fact that the Jain tradition is split into two sects, the “sky-clad” Digambara, whose male ascetics went naked, and the “white-clad” Śvetāmbara who wear an unstitched cloth. Jain tradition holds that the split occurred about a century later, in the reign of Candragupta Maurya.
comment_text.mn104:2.4: A slight on the movement whose signature virtue was non-violence.
comment_text.mn104:2.5: “With broken monument” (bhinnathupe) is used only in this context. When a great teacher or leader died, a “monument” was built to keep their memory alive. The breaking of a monument—whether physical or symbolic—was, in a way, truly killing them.
comment_text.mn104:3.1: Cunda took the time to complete his rains residence before conveying the news, reminding us of the speed with which news traveled in those days—slowly. For Cunda’s identity, see the note to MN 8:2.1 | Apart from the events described here, we hear of Sāma only once (AN 6.21). The topic there is the decline of the Saṅgha, hinting at a connection with these events.
comment_text.mn104:5.2: Two brahmins have a “difference of opinion” (nānāvāda) regarding their path at DN 13:8.8.
comment_text.mn104:5.6: As in the quarrel at Kosambī (MN 48, Kd 10).
comment_text.mn104:5.8: Just as the “phrasing” of the text is a minor matter at MN 103:7.12.
comment_text.mn104:5.9: This refers back to the teachings the Buddha has summarized above.
comment_text.mn104:6.1: The Buddha is more concerned with the unskillful roots of division than with the surface details. The first four pairs of “roots” are also found as “corruptions of mind” at MN 7:3.1.
comment_text.mn104:12.3: These are formal legal proceedings in the Vinaya, explained at Kd 14:14.2.1. | Here and below I follow the renderings of Brahmali for legal terms.
comment_text.mn104:13.1: Explained in more detail in the Vinaya (Kd 14:14.16.1).
comment_text.mn104:14.4: Samanumajjati occurs only here. The root majj has the general sense “stroke, massage”. Here it means that they should go over and over until it is settled. | Dhammanetti (“the guidelines of the teaching”) is another rare term, occurring elsewhere only in the late canonical Mil 6.3.12:7.5.
comment_text.mn104:15.1: This explanation is out of order, as it is listed as the second item here, but it is normally the fifth item, as in the summary above.
comment_text.mn104:15.2: Normally issues are settled by consensus, so this applies in cases where consensus cannot be reached.
comment_text.mn104:16.5: The Vinaya operates on good faith, so that the testimony of a clear-headed mendicant is sufficient to clear them from offences in most cases.
comment_text.mn104:17.2: The offenses entailing expulsion for a mendicant are: willingly engaging in sexual intercourse; intentional killing of a human being; theft of something of value; and deliberately making a false claim to exalted spiritual attainments such as awakening or absorption. | Pali editions vary as to whether the accuser is singular or plural. However, even those editions that use the plural here (Mahāsaṅgīti, PTS) shift to singular below (MN 104:17.6, MN 104:19.2), while in the Vinaya it is also singular (Kd 14:14.29.7).
comment_text.mn104:17.12: This evidently refers to an episode of psychosis, during which time a person is subject to hallucinations and delusions, and may exhibit bizarre behavior. There is a blanket exemption in Vinaya for all acts committed in such a state.
comment_text.mn104:18.3: This is the standard way of clearing offenses by confessing them as soon as they are recalled and recognized. Mendicants still confess with this formula today. Most offenses can be cleared in this way, but others require the relinquishment of a certain object (such as money), or undergoing a period of probation, while expulsion offenses cannot be cleared.
comment_text.mn104:19.1: “Further penalty” renders tassapāpiyasikā, more literally “what is worse for him”. In this case, a mendicant tries to deny the accusation but ends up just making it worse.
comment_text.mn104:19.6: Normally the mendicant’s denial is sufficient, but the case might be pressed if there is substantial evidence.
comment_text.mn104:20.11: Those that are “gravely blameworthy” include offenses of expulsion (pārājika) and suspension (saṅghādisesa), while those “connected with laypeople” include cases where the mendicant abuses the laity.
comment_text.mn104:20.12: This final method is a reminder that it is not always necessary to dig down to the bottom of every dispute, especially when blame accrues to both sides. Sometimes the most important thing is to move forward.
comment_text.mn104:21.1: Also taught at MN 48:6.2, AN 6.11:1.1, and AN 6.12:1.1, and collected at DN 33:2.2.37 and DN 34:1.7.3.

root_text.mn104:1.2: ekaṁ samayaṁ bhagavā sakkesu viharati sāmagāme.
root_text.mn104:2.1: Tena kho pana samayena nigaṇṭho nāṭaputto pāvāyaṁ adhunākālaṅkato hoti.
root_text.mn104:2.2: Tassa kālaṅkiriyāya bhinnā nigaṇṭhā dvedhikajātā bhaṇḍanajātā kalahajātā vivādāpannā aññamaññaṁ mukhasattīhi vitudantā viharanti:
root_text.mn104:2.3: “na tvaṁ imaṁ dhammavinayaṁ ājānāsi, ahaṁ imaṁ dhammavinayaṁ ājānāmi. Kiṁ tvaṁ imaṁ dhammavinayaṁ ājānissasi. Micchāpaṭipanno tvamasi, ahamasmi sammāpaṭipanno. Sahitaṁ me, asahitaṁ te. Purevacanīyaṁ pacchā avaca, pacchāvacanīyaṁ pure avaca. Adhiciṇṇaṁ te viparāvattaṁ. Āropito te vādo. Niggahitosi, cara vādappamokkhāya; nibbeṭhehi vā sace pahosī”ti.
root_text.mn104:2.4: Vadhoyeva kho maññe nigaṇṭhesu nāṭaputtiyesu vattati.
root_text.mn104:2.5: Yepi nigaṇṭhassa nāṭaputtassa sāvakā gihī odātavasanā tepi nigaṇṭhesu nāṭaputtiyesu nibbinnarūpā virattarūpā paṭivānarūpā yathā taṁ durakkhāte dhammavinaye duppavedite aniyyānike anupasamasaṁvattanike asammāsambuddhappavedite bhinnathūpe appaṭisaraṇe.
root_text.mn104:3.1: Atha kho cundo samaṇuddeso pāvāyaṁ vassaṁvuṭṭho yena sāmagāmo yenāyasmā ānando tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā āyasmantaṁ ānandaṁ abhivādetvā ekamantaṁ nisīdi. Ekamantaṁ nisinno kho cundo samaṇuddeso āyasmantaṁ ānandaṁ etadavoca:
root_text.mn104:3.3: Tassa kālaṅkiriyāya bhinnā nigaṇṭhā dvedhikajātā …pe… bhinnathūpe appaṭisaraṇe”ti.
root_text.mn104:4.1: Evaṁ vutte, āyasmā ānando cundaṁ samaṇuddesaṁ etadavoca:
root_text.mn104:4.2: “atthi kho idaṁ, āvuso cunda, kathāpābhataṁ bhagavantaṁ dassanāya.
root_text.mn104:4.3: Āyāma, āvuso cunda, yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkamissāma; upasaṅkamitvā etamatthaṁ bhagavato ārocessāmā”ti.
root_text.mn104:4.4: “Evaṁ, bhante”ti kho cundo samaṇuddeso āyasmato ānandassa paccassosi.
root_text.mn104:4.5: Atha kho āyasmā ca ānando cundo ca samaṇuddeso yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkamiṁsu; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṁ abhivādetvā ekamantaṁ nisīdiṁsu. Ekamantaṁ nisinno kho āyasmā ānando bhagavantaṁ etadavoca:
root_text.mn104:4.8: Tassa kālaṅkiriyāya bhinnā nigaṇṭhā dvedhikajātā …pe… bhinnathūpe appaṭisaraṇe’ti.
root_text.mn104:4.10: ‘mā heva bhagavato accayena saṅghe vivādo uppajji;
root_text.mn104:4.11: svāssa vivādo bahujanāhitāya bahujanāsukhāya bahuno janassa anatthāya ahitāya dukkhāya devamanussānan’”ti.
root_text.mn104:5.2: ye vo mayā dhammā abhiññā desitā, seyyathidaṁ—
root_text.mn104:5.3: cattāro satipaṭṭhānā cattāro sammappadhānā cattāro iddhipādā pañcindriyāni pañca balāni satta bojjhaṅgā ariyo aṭṭhaṅgiko maggo, passasi no tvaṁ, ānanda, imesu dhammesu dvepi bhikkhū nānāvāde”ti?
root_text.mn104:5.4: “Ye me, bhante, dhammā bhagavatā abhiññā desitā, seyyathidaṁ—
root_text.mn104:5.5: cattāro satipaṭṭhānā cattāro sammappadhānā cattāro iddhipādā pañcindriyāni pañca balāni satta bojjhaṅgā ariyo aṭṭhaṅgiko maggo, nāhaṁ passāmi imesu dhammesu dvepi bhikkhū nānāvāde.
root_text.mn104:5.6: Ye ca kho, bhante, puggalā bhagavantaṁ patissayamānarūpā viharanti tepi bhagavato accayena saṅghe vivādaṁ janeyyuṁ ajjhājīve vā adhipātimokkhe vā.
root_text.mn104:5.7: Svāssa vivādo bahujanāhitāya bahujanāsukhāya bahuno janassa anatthāya ahitāya dukkhāya devamanussānan”ti.
root_text.mn104:5.8: “Appamattako so, ānanda, vivādo yadidaṁ—ajjhājīve vā adhipātimokkhe vā.
root_text.mn104:5.9: Magge vā hi, ānanda, paṭipadāya vā saṅghe vivādo uppajjamāno uppajjeyya; svāssa vivādo bahujanāhitāya bahujanāsukhāya bahuno janassa anatthāya ahitāya dukkhāya devamanussānaṁ.
root_text.mn104:6.4: Yo so, ānanda, bhikkhu kodhano hoti upanāhī so sattharipi agāravo viharati appatisso, dhammepi agāravo viharati appatisso, saṅghepi agāravo viharati appatisso, sikkhāyapi na paripūrakārī hoti.
root_text.mn104:6.5: Yo so, ānanda, bhikkhu satthari agāravo viharati appatisso, dhamme … saṅghe agāravo viharati appatisso, sikkhāya na paripūrakārī hoti, so saṅghe vivādaṁ janeti; yo hoti vivādo bahujanāhitāya bahujanāsukhāya, bahuno janassa anatthāya ahitāya dukkhāya devamanussānaṁ.
root_text.mn104:6.6: Evarūpañce tumhe, ānanda, vivādamūlaṁ ajjhattaṁ vā bahiddhā vā samanupasseyyātha, tatra tumhe, ānanda, tasseva pāpakassa vivādamūlassa pahānāya vāyameyyātha.
root_text.mn104:6.7: Evarūpañce tumhe, ānanda, vivādamūlaṁ ajjhattaṁ vā bahiddhā vā na samanupasseyyātha. Tatra tumhe, ānanda, tasseva pāpakassa vivādamūlassa āyatiṁ anavassavāya paṭipajjeyyātha.
root_text.mn104:6.8: Evametassa pāpakassa vivādamūlassa pahānaṁ hoti, evametassa pāpakassa vivādamūlassa āyatiṁ anavassavo hoti.
root_text.mn104:7-11.1: Puna caparaṁ, ānanda, bhikkhu makkhī hoti paḷāsī …pe…
root_text.mn104:7-11.6: Yo so, ānanda, bhikkhu sandiṭṭhiparāmāsī hoti ādhānaggāhī duppaṭinissaggī so sattharipi agāravo viharati appatisso, dhammepi agāravo viharati appatisso, saṅghepi agāravo viharati appatisso, sikkhāyapi na paripūrakārī hoti.
root_text.mn104:7-11.7: Yo so, ānanda, bhikkhu satthari agāravo viharati appatisso, dhamme … saṅghe … sikkhāya na paripūrakārī hoti so saṅghe vivādaṁ janeti; yo hoti vivādo bahujanāhitāya bahujanāsukhāya, bahuno janassa anatthāya ahitāya dukkhāya devamanussānaṁ.
root_text.mn104:7-11.8: Evarūpañce tumhe, ānanda, vivādamūlaṁ ajjhattaṁ vā bahiddhā vā samanupasseyyātha. Tatra tumhe, ānanda, tasseva pāpakassa vivādamūlassa pahānāya vāyameyyātha.
root_text.mn104:7-11.9: Evarūpañce tumhe, ānanda, vivādamūlaṁ ajjhattaṁ vā bahiddhā vā na samanupasseyyātha, tatra tumhe, ānanda, tasseva pāpakassa vivādamūlassa āyatiṁ anavassavāya paṭipajjeyyātha.
root_text.mn104:7-11.10: Evametassa pāpakassa vivādamūlassa pahānaṁ hoti, evametassa pāpakassa vivādamūlassa āyatiṁ anavassavo hoti.
root_text.mn104:13.1: Satta kho panime, ānanda, adhikaraṇasamathā uppannuppannānaṁ adhikaraṇānaṁ samathāya vūpasamāya—
root_text.mn104:13.2: sammukhāvinayo dātabbo, sativinayo dātabbo, amūḷhavinayo dātabbo, paṭiññāya kāretabbaṁ, yebhuyyasikā, tassapāpiyasikā, tiṇavatthārako.
root_text.mn104:14.2: Idhānanda, bhikkhū vivadanti dhammoti vā adhammoti vā vinayoti vā avinayoti vā.
root_text.mn104:14.5: Dhammanettiṁ samanumajjitvā yathā tattha sameti tathā taṁ adhikaraṇaṁ vūpasametabbaṁ.
root_text.mn104:14.7: evañca panidhekaccānaṁ adhikaraṇānaṁ vūpasamo hoti yadidaṁ—
root_text.mn104:15.2: Te ce, ānanda, bhikkhū na sakkonti taṁ adhikaraṇaṁ tasmiṁ āvāse vūpasametuṁ.
root_text.mn104:15.3: Tehānanda, bhikkhūhi yasmiṁ āvāse bahutarā bhikkhū so āvāso gantabbo.
root_text.mn104:15.6: Dhammanettiṁ samanumajjitvā yathā tattha sameti tathā taṁ adhikaraṇaṁ vūpasametabbaṁ.
root_text.mn104:15.7: Evaṁ kho, ānanda, yebhuyyasikā hoti, evañca panidhekaccānaṁ adhikaraṇānaṁ vūpasamo hoti yadidaṁ—
root_text.mn104:16.2: Idhānanda, bhikkhū bhikkhuṁ evarūpāya garukāya āpattiyā codenti pārājikena vā pārājikasāmantena vā:
root_text.mn104:16.3: ‘saratāyasmā evarūpiṁ garukaṁ āpattiṁ āpajjitā pārājikaṁ vā pārājikasāmantaṁ vā’ti?
root_text.mn104:16.5: ‘na kho ahaṁ, āvuso, sarāmi evarūpiṁ garukaṁ āpattiṁ āpajjitā pārājikaṁ vā pārājikasāmantaṁ vā’ti.
root_text.mn104:16.6: Tassa kho, ānanda, bhikkhuno sativinayo dātabbo.
root_text.mn104:16.7: Evaṁ kho, ānanda, sativinayo hoti, evañca panidhekaccānaṁ adhikaraṇānaṁ vūpasamo hoti yadidaṁ—
root_text.mn104:17.2: Idhānanda, bhikkhū bhikkhuṁ evarūpāya garukāya āpattiyā codenti pārājikena vā pārājikasāmantena vā:
root_text.mn104:17.3: ‘saratāyasmā evarūpiṁ garukaṁ āpattiṁ āpajjitā pārājikaṁ vā pārājikasāmantaṁ vā’ti?
root_text.mn104:17.5: ‘na kho ahaṁ, āvuso, sarāmi evarūpiṁ garukaṁ āpattiṁ āpajjitā pārājikaṁ vā pārājikasāmantaṁ vā’ti.
root_text.mn104:17.7: ‘iṅghāyasmā sādhukameva jānāhi yadi sarasi evarūpiṁ garukaṁ āpattiṁ āpajjitā pārājikaṁ vā pārājikasāmantaṁ vā’ti.
root_text.mn104:17.9: ‘ahaṁ kho, āvuso, ummādaṁ pāpuṇiṁ cetaso vipariyāsaṁ.
root_text.mn104:17.10: Tena me ummattakena bahuṁ assāmaṇakaṁ ajjhāciṇṇaṁ bhāsitaparikkantaṁ.
root_text.mn104:17.13: Tassa kho, ānanda, bhikkhuno amūḷhavinayo dātabbo.
root_text.mn104:17.14: Evaṁ kho, ānanda, amūḷhavinayo hoti, evañca panidhekaccānaṁ adhikaraṇānaṁ vūpasamo hoti yadidaṁ—
root_text.mn104:18.2: Idhānanda, bhikkhu codito vā acodito vā āpattiṁ sarati, vivarati uttānīkaroti.
root_text.mn104:18.3: Tena, ānanda, bhikkhunā vuḍḍhataraṁ bhikkhuṁ upasaṅkamitvā ekaṁsaṁ cīvaraṁ katvā pāde vanditvā ukkuṭikaṁ nisīditvā añjaliṁ paggahetvā evamassa vacanīyo:
root_text.mn104:18.4: ‘ahaṁ, bhante, itthannāmaṁ āpattiṁ āpanno, taṁ paṭidesemī’ti.
root_text.mn104:18.10: Evaṁ kho, ānanda, paṭiññātakaraṇaṁ hoti, evañca panidhekaccānaṁ adhikaraṇānaṁ vūpasamo hoti yadidaṁ—
root_text.mn104:19.2: Idhānanda, bhikkhu bhikkhuṁ evarūpāya garukāya āpattiyā codeti pārājikena vā pārājikasāmantena vā:
root_text.mn104:19.3: ‘saratāyasmā evarūpiṁ garukaṁ āpattiṁ āpajjitā pārājikaṁ vā pārājikasāmantaṁ vā’ti?
root_text.mn104:19.5: ‘na kho ahaṁ, āvuso, sarāmi evarūpiṁ garukaṁ āpattiṁ āpajjitā pārājikaṁ vā pārājikasāmantaṁ vā’ti.
root_text.mn104:19.7: ‘iṅghāyasmā sādhukameva jānāhi yadi sarasi evarūpiṁ garukaṁ āpattiṁ āpajjitā pārājikaṁ vā pārājikasāmantaṁ vā’ti.
root_text.mn104:19.9: ‘na kho ahaṁ, āvuso, sarāmi evarūpiṁ garukaṁ āpattiṁ āpajjitā pārājikaṁ vā pārājikasāmantaṁ vā;
root_text.mn104:19.10: sarāmi ca kho ahaṁ, āvuso, evarūpiṁ appamattikaṁ āpattiṁ āpajjitā’ti.
root_text.mn104:19.12: ‘iṅghāyasmā sādhukameva jānāhi yadi sarasi evarūpiṁ garukaṁ āpattiṁ āpajjitā pārājikaṁ vā pārājikasāmantaṁ vā’ti?
root_text.mn104:19.14: ‘imañhi nāmāhaṁ, āvuso, appamattikaṁ āpattiṁ āpajjitvā apuṭṭho paṭijānissāmi.
root_text.mn104:19.15: Kiṁ panāhaṁ evarūpiṁ garukaṁ āpattiṁ āpajjitvā pārājikaṁ vā pārājikasāmantaṁ vā puṭṭho na paṭijānissāmī’ti?
root_text.mn104:19.17: ‘imañhi nāma tvaṁ, āvuso, appamattikaṁ āpattiṁ āpajjitvā apuṭṭho na paṭijānissasi, kiṁ pana tvaṁ evarūpiṁ garukaṁ āpattiṁ āpajjitvā pārājikaṁ vā pārājikasāmantaṁ vā puṭṭho paṭijānissasi?
root_text.mn104:19.18: Iṅghāyasmā sādhukameva jānāhi yadi sarasi evarūpiṁ garukaṁ āpattiṁ āpajjitā pārājikaṁ vā pārājikasāmantaṁ vā’ti.
root_text.mn104:19.20: ‘sarāmi kho ahaṁ, āvuso, evarūpiṁ garukaṁ āpattiṁ āpajjitā pārājikaṁ vā pārājikasāmantaṁ vā.
root_text.mn104:19.21: Davā me etaṁ vuttaṁ, ravā me etaṁ vuttaṁ—
root_text.mn104:19.22: nāhaṁ taṁ sarāmi evarūpiṁ garukaṁ āpattiṁ āpajjitā pārājikaṁ vā pārājikasāmantaṁ vā’ti.
root_text.mn104:19.23: Evaṁ kho, ānanda, tassapāpiyasikā hoti, evañca panidhekaccānaṁ adhikaraṇānaṁ vūpasamo hoti yadidaṁ—
root_text.mn104:20.2: Idhānanda, bhikkhūnaṁ bhaṇḍanajātānaṁ kalahajātānaṁ vivādāpannānaṁ viharataṁ bahuṁ assāmaṇakaṁ ajjhāciṇṇaṁ hoti bhāsitaparikkantaṁ.
root_text.mn104:20.4: Sannipatitvā ekatopakkhikānaṁ bhikkhūnaṁ byattena bhikkhunā uṭṭhāyāsanā ekaṁsaṁ cīvaraṁ katvā añjaliṁ paṇāmetvā saṅgho ñāpetabbo—
root_text.mn104:20.6: Idaṁ amhākaṁ bhaṇḍanajātānaṁ kalahajātānaṁ vivādāpannānaṁ viharataṁ bahuṁ assāmaṇakaṁ ajjhāciṇṇaṁ bhāsitaparikkantaṁ.
root_text.mn104:20.7: Yadi saṅghassa pattakallaṁ, ahaṁ yā ceva imesaṁ āyasmantānaṁ āpatti yā ca attano āpatti, imesañceva āyasmantānaṁ atthāya attano ca atthāya, saṅghamajjhe tiṇavatthārakena deseyyaṁ, ṭhapetvā thullavajjaṁ ṭhapetvā gihipaṭisaṁyuttan’ti.
root_text.mn104:20.8: Athāparesaṁ ekatopakkhikānaṁ bhikkhūnaṁ byattena bhikkhunā uṭṭhāyāsanā ekaṁsaṁ cīvaraṁ katvā añjaliṁ paṇāmetvā saṅgho ñāpetabbo:
root_text.mn104:20.10: Idaṁ amhākaṁ bhaṇḍanajātānaṁ kalahajātānaṁ vivādāpannānaṁ viharataṁ bahuṁ assāmaṇakaṁ ajjhāciṇṇaṁ bhāsitaparikkantaṁ.
root_text.mn104:20.11: Yadi saṅghassa pattakallaṁ, ahaṁ yā ceva imesaṁ āyasmantānaṁ āpatti yā ca attano āpatti, imesañceva āyasmantānaṁ atthāya attano ca atthāya, saṅghamajjhe tiṇavatthārakena deseyyaṁ, ṭhapetvā thullavajjaṁ ṭhapetvā gihipaṭisaṁyuttan’ti.
root_text.mn104:20.12: Evaṁ kho, ānanda, tiṇavatthārako hoti, evañca panidhekaccānaṁ adhikaraṇānaṁ vūpasamo hoti yadidaṁ—
root_text.mn104:21.1: Chayime, ānanda, dhammā sāraṇīyā piyakaraṇā garukaraṇā saṅgahāya avivādāya sāmaggiyā ekībhāvāya saṁvattanti.
root_text.mn104:21.3: Idhānanda, bhikkhuno mettaṁ kāyakammaṁ paccupaṭṭhitaṁ hoti sabrahmacārīsu āvi ceva raho ca.
root_text.mn104:21.4: Ayampi dhammo sāraṇīyo piyakaraṇo garukaraṇo saṅgahāya avivādāya sāmaggiyā ekībhāvāya saṁvattati.
root_text.mn104:21.5: Puna caparaṁ, ānanda, bhikkhuno mettaṁ vacīkammaṁ paccupaṭṭhitaṁ hoti sabrahmacārīsu āvi ceva raho ca.
root_text.mn104:21.6: Ayampi dhammo sāraṇīyo piyakaraṇo garukaraṇo saṅgahāya avivādāya sāmaggiyā ekībhāvāya saṁvattati.
root_text.mn104:21.7: Puna caparaṁ, ānanda, bhikkhuno mettaṁ manokammaṁ paccupaṭṭhitaṁ hoti sabrahmacārīsu āvi ceva raho ca.
root_text.mn104:21.8: Ayampi dhammo sāraṇīyo piyakaraṇo garukaraṇo saṅgahāya avivādāya sāmaggiyā ekībhāvāya saṁvattati.
root_text.mn104:21.9: Puna caparaṁ, ānanda, bhikkhu—ye te lābhā dhammikā dhammaladdhā antamaso pattapariyāpannamattampi tathārūpehi lābhehi—apaṭivibhattabhogī hoti, sīlavantehi sabrahmacārīhi sādhāraṇabhogī.
root_text.mn104:21.10: Ayampi dhammo sāraṇīyo piyakaraṇo garukaraṇo saṅgahāya avivādāya sāmaggiyā ekībhāvāya saṁvattati.
root_text.mn104:21.11: Puna caparaṁ, ānanda, bhikkhu—yāni tāni sīlāni akhaṇḍāni acchiddāni asabalāni akammāsāni bhujissāni viññuppasatthāni aparāmaṭṭhāni samādhisaṁvattanikāni tathārūpesu sīlesu—sīlasāmaññagato viharati sabrahmacārīhi āvi ceva raho ca.
root_text.mn104:21.12: Ayampi dhammo sāraṇīyo piyakaraṇo garukaraṇo saṅgahāya avivādāya sāmaggiyā ekībhāvāya saṁvattati.
root_text.mn104:21.13: Puna caparaṁ, ānanda, bhikkhu—yāyaṁ diṭṭhi ariyā niyyānikā niyyāti takkarassa sammā dukkhakkhayāya tathārūpāya diṭṭhiyā—diṭṭhisāmaññagato viharati sabrahmacārīhi āvi ceva raho ca.
root_text.mn104:21.14: Ayampi dhammo sāraṇīyo piyakaraṇo garukaraṇo saṅgahāya avivādāya sāmaggiyā ekībhāvāya saṁvattati.
root_text.mn104:21.15: Ime kho, ānanda, cha sāraṇīyā dhammā piyakaraṇā garukaraṇā saṅgahāya avivādāya sāmaggiyā ekībhāvāya saṁvattanti.
root_text.mn104:22.1: Ime ce tumhe, ānanda, cha sāraṇīye dhamme samādāya vatteyyātha, passatha no tumhe, ānanda, taṁ vacanapathaṁ aṇuṁ vā thūlaṁ vā yaṁ tumhe nādhivāseyyāthā”ti?
root_text.mn104:22.3: “Tasmātihānanda, ime cha sāraṇīye dhamme samādāya vattatha.
root_text.mn104:22.4: Taṁ vo bhavissati dīgharattaṁ hitāya sukhāyā”ti.
root_text.mn104:22.6: Attamano āyasmā ānando bhagavato bhāsitaṁ abhinandīti.

translation_text.mn104:1.2: At one time the Buddha was staying in the land of the Sakyans near the village of Sāma.
translation_text.mn104:2.1: Now at that time the Jain ascetic of the Ñātika clan had recently passed away at Pāvā.
translation_text.mn104:2.2: With his passing the Jain ascetics split, dividing into two factions, fighting, quarreling, and disputing, continually wounding each other with barbed words:
translation_text.mn104:2.3: “You don’t understand this teaching and training. I understand this teaching and training. What, you understand this teaching and training? You’re practicing wrong. I’m practicing right. I stay on topic, you don’t. You said last what you should have said first. You said first what you should have said last. What you’ve thought so much about has been disproved. Your doctrine is refuted. Go on, save your doctrine! You’re trapped; get yourself out of this—if you can!”
translation_text.mn104:2.4: You’d think there was nothing but slaughter going on among the Jain ascetics.
translation_text.mn104:2.5: And the Jain Ñātika’s white-clothed lay disciples were disillusioned, dismayed, and disappointed in the Jain ascetics. They were equally disappointed with a teaching and training so poorly explained and poorly propounded, not emancipating, not leading to peace, proclaimed by someone who is not a fully awakened Buddha, with broken monument and without a refuge.
translation_text.mn104:3.1: And then, after completing the rainy season residence near Pāvā, the novice Cunda went to see Venerable Ānanda at Sāma village. He bowed, sat down to one side, and told him what had happened.
translation_text.mn104:4.2: “Reverend Cunda, we should see the Buddha about this matter.
translation_text.mn104:4.3: Come, let’s go to the Buddha and inform him about this.”
translation_text.mn104:4.5: Then Ānanda and Cunda went to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and Ānanda informed him of what Cunda had said. He went on to say,
translation_text.mn104:4.10: ‘When the Buddha has passed away, let no dispute arise in the Saṅgha.
translation_text.mn104:4.11: For such a dispute would be for the detriment and suffering of the people, against the people, for the harm, detriment, and suffering of gods and humans.’”
translation_text.mn104:5.2: Do you see even two mendicants whose opinion differs regarding the things I have taught from my direct knowledge, that is,
translation_text.mn104:5.3: the four kinds of mindfulness meditation, the four right efforts, the four bases of psychic power, the five faculties, the five powers, the seven awakening factors, and the noble eightfold path?”
translation_text.mn104:5.6: Nevertheless, there are some individuals who appear to live obedient to the Buddha, but when the Buddha has passed away they might create a dispute in the Saṅgha regarding livelihood or the monastic code.
translation_text.mn104:5.7: Such a dispute would be for the detriment and suffering of the people, against the people, for the harm, detriment, and suffering of gods and humans.”
translation_text.mn104:5.8: “Ānanda, dispute about livelihood or the monastic code is a minor matter.
translation_text.mn104:5.9: But should a dispute arise in the Saṅgha concerning the path or the practice, that would be for the detriment and suffering of the people, against the people, for the harm, detriment, and suffering of gods and humans.
translation_text.mn104:6.1: Ānanda, there are these six roots of dispute.
translation_text.mn104:6.3: Firstly, a mendicant is irritable and acrimonious.
translation_text.mn104:6.4: Such a mendicant lacks respect and reverence for the teacher, the teaching, and the Saṅgha, and they don’t fulfill the training.
translation_text.mn104:6.5: They create a dispute in the Saṅgha, which is for the detriment and suffering of the people, against the people, for the harm, detriment, and suffering of gods and humans.
translation_text.mn104:6.6: If you see such a root of dispute in yourselves or others, you should try to give up this bad thing.
translation_text.mn104:6.7: If you don’t see it, you should practice so that it doesn’t come up in the future.
translation_text.mn104:6.8: That’s how to give up this bad root of dispute, so it doesn’t come up in the future.
translation_text.mn104:7-11.1: Furthermore, a mendicant is offensive and contemptuous …
translation_text.mn104:7-11.4: They have corrupt wishes and wrong view …
translation_text.mn104:7-11.5: They’re attached to their own views, holding them tight, and refusing to let go.
translation_text.mn104:7-11.6: Such a mendicant lacks respect and reverence for the teacher, the teaching, and the Saṅgha, and they don’t fulfill the training.
translation_text.mn104:7-11.7: They create a dispute in the Saṅgha, which is for the detriment and suffering of the people, against the people, for the harm, detriment, and suffering of gods and humans.
translation_text.mn104:7-11.8: If you see such a root of dispute in yourselves or others, you should try to give up this bad thing.
translation_text.mn104:7-11.9: If you don’t see it, you should practice so that it doesn’t come up in the future.
translation_text.mn104:7-11.10: That’s how to give up this bad root of dispute, so it doesn’t come up in the future.
translation_text.mn104:7-11.11: These are the six roots of dispute.
translation_text.mn104:12.1: There are four kinds of disciplinary issues.
translation_text.mn104:12.3: Disciplinary issues due to disputes, accusations, offenses, or business.
translation_text.mn104:12.4: These are the four kinds of disciplinary issues.
translation_text.mn104:13.1: There are seven methods for the settlement of any disciplinary issues that might arise.
translation_text.mn104:13.2: Resolution face-to-face to be applied. Resolution through recollection to be granted. Resolution because of past insanity to be granted. Acting according to what has been admitted. Majority decision. Further penalty. Covering over as if with grass.
translation_text.mn104:14.1: And how is there resolution face-to-face?
translation_text.mn104:14.2: It’s when mendicants are disputing: ‘This is the teaching,’ ‘This is not the teaching,’ ‘This is the monastic law,’ ‘This is not the monastic law.’
translation_text.mn104:14.3: Those mendicants should all sit together in harmony
translation_text.mn104:14.4: and thoroughly go over the guidelines of the teaching.
translation_text.mn104:14.5: They should settle that disciplinary issue in agreement with the guidelines.
translation_text.mn104:14.6: That’s how there is resolution face-to-face.
translation_text.mn104:14.7: And that’s how certain disciplinary issues are settled, that is,
translation_text.mn104:15.1: And how is there majority decision?
translation_text.mn104:15.2: If those mendicants are not able to settle that issue in that monastery,
translation_text.mn104:15.3: they should go to another monastery with more mendicants.
translation_text.mn104:15.4: There they should all sit together in harmony
translation_text.mn104:15.5: and thoroughly go over the guidelines of the teaching.
translation_text.mn104:15.6: They should settle that disciplinary issue in agreement with the guidelines.
translation_text.mn104:15.7: That’s how there is majority decision. And that’s how certain disciplinary issues are settled, that is,
translation_text.mn104:16.1: And how is there resolution through recollection?
translation_text.mn104:16.2: It’s when mendicants accuse a mendicant of a serious offense; one entailing expulsion, or close to it:
translation_text.mn104:16.3: ‘Venerable, do you recall committing the kind of serious offense that entails expulsion or close to it?’
translation_text.mn104:16.5: ‘No, reverends, I don’t recall committing such an offense.’
translation_text.mn104:16.6: The resolution through recollection should be granted to them.
translation_text.mn104:16.7: That’s how there is the resolution through recollection. And that’s how certain disciplinary issues are settled, that is,
translation_text.mn104:17.1: And how is there resolution because of past insanity?
translation_text.mn104:17.2: It’s when a mendicant accuses a mendicant of the kind of serious offense that entails expulsion, or close to it:
translation_text.mn104:17.3: ‘Venerable, do you recall committing the kind of serious offense that entails expulsion or close to it?’
translation_text.mn104:17.5: ‘No, reverend, I don’t recall committing such an offense.’
translation_text.mn104:17.6: But though they try to get out of it, the mendicant pursues the issue:
translation_text.mn104:17.7: ‘Surely the venerable must know perfectly well if you recall committing an offense that entails expulsion or close to it!’
translation_text.mn104:17.9: ‘Reverend, I had gone mad, I was out of my mind.
translation_text.mn104:17.10: And while I was mad I did and said many things that are not proper for an ascetic.
translation_text.mn104:17.11: I don’t remember any of that,
translation_text.mn104:17.12: I was mad when I did it.’
translation_text.mn104:17.13: The resolution because of past insanity should be granted to them.
translation_text.mn104:17.14: That’s how there is resolution because of past insanity. And that’s how certain disciplinary issues are settled, that is,
translation_text.mn104:17.15: by resolution because of past insanity.
translation_text.mn104:18.1: And how is there acting according to what has been admitted?
translation_text.mn104:18.2: It’s when a mendicant, whether accused or not, recalls an offense and clarifies it and reveals it.
translation_text.mn104:18.3: After approaching a more senior mendicant, that mendicant should arrange his robe over one shoulder, bow to that mendicant’s feet, squat on their heels, raise their joined palms, and say:
translation_text.mn104:18.4: ‘Sir, I have fallen into such-and-such an offense. I confess it.’
translation_text.mn104:18.10: That’s how there is acting according to what has been admitted. And that’s how certain disciplinary issues are settled, that is,
translation_text.mn104:18.11: by acting according to what has been admitted.
translation_text.mn104:19.1: And how is there a verdict of further penalty?
translation_text.mn104:19.2: It’s when a mendicant accuses a mendicant of the kind of serious offense that entails expulsion, or close to it:
translation_text.mn104:19.3: ‘Venerable, do you recall committing the kind of serious offense that entails expulsion or close to it?’
translation_text.mn104:19.5: ‘No, reverends, I don’t recall committing such an offense.’
translation_text.mn104:19.6: But though they try to get out of it, the mendicants pursue the issue:
translation_text.mn104:19.7: ‘Surely the venerable must know perfectly well if you recall committing an offense that entails expulsion or close to it!’
translation_text.mn104:19.9: ‘Reverends, I don’t recall committing a serious offense of that nature.
translation_text.mn104:19.10: But I do recall committing a light offense.’
translation_text.mn104:19.11: But though they try to get out of it, the mendicants pursue the issue:
translation_text.mn104:19.12: ‘Surely the venerable must know perfectly well if you recall committing an offense that entails expulsion or close to it!’
translation_text.mn104:19.14: ‘Reverends, I’ll go so far as to admit this light offense even when not asked.
translation_text.mn104:19.15: Why wouldn’t I admit a serious offense when asked?’
translation_text.mn104:19.17: ‘You wouldn’t have admitted that light offense without being asked, so why would you admit a serious offense?
translation_text.mn104:19.18: Surely the venerable must know perfectly well if you recall committing an offense that entails expulsion or close to it!’
translation_text.mn104:19.20: ‘Reverend, I do recall committing the kind of serious offense that entails expulsion or close to it.
translation_text.mn104:19.21: I spoke too hastily when I said
translation_text.mn104:19.23: That’s how there is further penalty. And that’s how certain disciplinary issues are settled, that is,
translation_text.mn104:20.1: And how is there the covering over as if with grass?
translation_text.mn104:20.2: It’s when the mendicants continually fight, quarrel, and dispute, doing and saying many things that are not proper for an ascetic.
translation_text.mn104:20.3: Those mendicants should all sit together in harmony.
translation_text.mn104:20.4: A competent mendicant of one party, having got up from their seat, arranged their robe over one shoulder, and raised their joined palms, should inform the Saṅgha:
translation_text.mn104:20.5: ‘Sir, let the Saṅgha listen to me.
translation_text.mn104:20.6: We have been continually fighting, quarreling, and disputing, doing and saying many things that are not proper for an ascetic.
translation_text.mn104:20.7: If it seems appropriate to the Saṅgha, then—for the benefit of these venerables and myself—I disclose in the middle of the Saṅgha by means of covering over as if with grass any offenses committed by these venerables and by myself, excepting only those that are gravely blameworthy and those connected with laypeople.’
translation_text.mn104:20.8: Then a competent mendicant of the other party, having got up from their seat, arranged their robe over one shoulder, and raising their joined palms, should inform the Saṅgha:
translation_text.mn104:20.9: ‘Sir, let the Saṅgha listen to me.
translation_text.mn104:20.10: We have been continually fighting, quarreling, and disputing, doing and saying many things that are not proper for an ascetic.
translation_text.mn104:20.11: If it seems appropriate to the Saṅgha, then—for the benefit of these venerables and myself—I disclose in the middle of the Saṅgha by means of covering over as if with grass any offenses committed by these venerables and by myself, excepting only those that are gravely blameworthy and those connected with laypeople.’
translation_text.mn104:20.12: That’s how there is the covering over as if with grass. And that’s how certain disciplinary issues are settled, that is,
translation_text.mn104:20.13: by covering over as if with grass.
translation_text.mn104:21.1: Ānanda, these six warm-hearted qualities make for fondness and respect, conducing to inclusion, harmony, and unity, without quarreling.
translation_text.mn104:21.3: Firstly, a mendicant consistently treats their spiritual companions with bodily kindness, both in public and in private.
translation_text.mn104:21.4: This warm-hearted quality makes for fondness and respect, conducing to inclusion, harmony, and unity, without dispute.
translation_text.mn104:21.5: Furthermore, a mendicant consistently treats their spiritual companions with verbal kindness …
translation_text.mn104:21.6: This too is a warm-hearted quality.
translation_text.mn104:21.7: Furthermore, a mendicant consistently treats their spiritual companions with mental kindness …
translation_text.mn104:21.8: This too is a warm-hearted quality.
translation_text.mn104:21.9: Furthermore, a mendicant shares without reservation any material things they have gained by legitimate means, even the food placed in the alms-bowl, using them in common with their ethical spiritual companions.
translation_text.mn104:21.10: This too is a warm-hearted quality.
translation_text.mn104:21.11: Furthermore, a mendicant lives according to the precepts shared with their spiritual companions, both in public and in private. Those precepts are intact, impeccable, spotless, and unmarred, liberating, praised by sensible people, not mistaken, and leading to immersion.
translation_text.mn104:21.12: This too is a warm-hearted quality.
translation_text.mn104:21.13: Furthermore, a mendicant lives according to the view shared with their spiritual companions, both in public and in private. That view is noble and emancipating, and delivers one who practices it to the complete ending of suffering.
translation_text.mn104:21.14: This too is a warm-hearted quality.
translation_text.mn104:21.15: These six warm-hearted qualities make for fondness and respect, conducing to inclusion, harmony, and unity, without dispute.
translation_text.mn104:22.1: If you should undertake and follow these six warm-hearted qualities, do you see any criticism, large or small, that you could not endure?”
translation_text.mn104:22.3: “That’s why, Ānanda, you should undertake and follow these six warm-hearted qualities.
translation_text.mn104:22.4: That will be for your lasting welfare and happiness.”
translation_text.mn104:22.5: That is what the Buddha said.
translation_text.mn104:22.6: Satisfied, Venerable Ānanda approved what the Buddha said.
